articles.headline: To Perelman’s Failed Revlon Deal, Add Rebuke From S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that Revlon hid crucial information from its independent board members related to a complex corporate finance transaction that the company tried to execute with its minority shareholders.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that Revlon hid crucial information from its independent board members related to a complex corporate finance transaction that the company tried to execute with its minority shareholders.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Said to Plan to Send Weapons to Syrian Rebels
articles.snippet: Even with the decision to supply lethal aid to the rebels, the Obama administration remains deeply divided about whether to take more forceful action to try to quell the fighting.
articles.abstract: Even with the decision to supply lethal aid to the rebels, the Obama administration remains deeply divided about whether to take more forceful action to try to quell the fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, concluding that the troops of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria have used chemical weapons against rebel forces in his country’s civil war, has decided to begin supplying the rebels for the first time with small arms and ammunition, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: When Bernanke Confounds, Wall Street Reaches for Theories
articles.snippet: Amid the current turmoil in global markets, one question is being obsessively debated on Wall Street: Just what was Ben S. Bernanke thinking three weeks ago when he said that the Federal Reserve might soon cut back its stimulus efforts?
articles.abstract: Amid the current turmoil in global markets, one question is being obsessively debated on Wall Street: Just what was Ben S. Bernanke thinking three weeks ago when he said that the Federal Reserve might soon cut back its stimulus efforts?
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid the current turmoil in global markets, one question is being obsessively debated on Wall Street: Just what was Ben S. Bernanke thinking three weeks ago when he said that the Federal Reserve might soon cut back its stimulus efforts?

articles.headline: Going Dark, and Putting Blindfolds on Investors
articles.snippet: One company offers an example of what it means to “go dark,” without the need to file financial information with the S.E.C.
articles.abstract: One company offers an example of what it means to “go dark,” without the need to file financial information with the S.E.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: What happens to investors who buy securities issued under the protection of United States securities laws and continue to hold them after many of the protections are removed? Sometimes it is not pretty.

articles.headline: Venerable Format of ‘NewsHour’ Struggles With New Era of Media
articles.snippet: Layoffs and a financial crisis have exposed tension at the long-running news program, with some calling for a major overhaul.
articles.abstract: Layoffs and a financial crisis have exposed tension at the long-running news program, with some calling for a major overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many of its 38 years, the sober studio-interview format of the “PBS NewsHour” has served the program well, drawing viewers and corporate underwriters alike. But with a deep financing crisis forcing layoffs and other cutbacks this week, some public television employees believe that format — and a general unwillingness to embrace the digital realities facing journalism — may be jeopardizing the program’s future.

articles.headline: Apple Negotiator Defends Tactics in E-Book Trial
articles.snippet: Eddy Cue, a senior vice president for Apple, denied that the company colluded with publishers to fix e-book prices.
articles.abstract: Eddy Cue, a senior vice president for Apple, denied that the company colluded with publishers to fix e-book prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: A top executive at Apple who was a close associate of Steve Jobs said on Thursday that he had thrown himself into negotiations with the major publishing houses as Apple entered the e-book market because “Steve was near the end of his life.”

articles.headline: Secret Court Ruling Put Tech Companies in Data Bind
articles.snippet: In 2008, a ruling by a surveillance court said to be against Yahoo discouraged technology firms from fighting data requests from the government.
articles.abstract: In 2008, a ruling by a surveillance court said to be against Yahoo discouraged technology firms from fighting data requests from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a secret court in Washington, Yahoo’s top lawyers made their case. The government had sought help in spying on certain foreign users, without a warrant, and Yahoo had refused, saying the broad requests were unconstitutional.

articles.headline: Bloomberg Reporters’ Practices Become Crucial Issue for Company
articles.snippet: Many people claim the company encourages its news operation and business side to work together.
articles.abstract: Many people claim the company encourages its news operation and business side to work together.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most journalists dream of uncovering government corruption, landing a big interview or winning a Pulitzer Prize. But those are not the goals that Thomas F. Secunda, who co-founded Bloomberg L.P. in 1982 with Michael R. Bloomberg, has in mind.

articles.headline: Airbus Unveils Jet and Broadens Rivalry With Boeing
articles.snippet: As orders for military planes continue to drop, Airbus has placed a strong bet on commercial aircraft with the A350, a new wide-body jet.
articles.abstract: As orders for military planes continue to drop, Airbus has placed a strong bet on commercial aircraft with the A350, a new wide-body jet.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, France — The A350 XWB, the first all-new commercial jet from Airbus in more than six years, took wing into partly cloudy skies here on Friday.

articles.headline: Moderate in Iranian Election Leads in Initial Returns
articles.snippet: Iran’s interior minister said Saturday morning that preliminary results showed Hassan Rowhani, a cleric, with a strong lead, followed by the mayor of Tehran, Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf.
articles.abstract: Iran’s interior minister said Saturday morning that preliminary results showed Hassan Rowhani, a cleric, with a strong lead, followed by the mayor of Tehran, Mohammad Baqer Ghalibaf.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian voters turned out in huge numbers on Friday, a late surge of interest in the presidential vote that seemed to swing the tide in the favor of the most moderate candidate in the field. But it was uncertain whether any single contestant would exceed the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid a runoff next week.
